references: Enlightened by Observations 3, we realize that compared with randomly adding edges, linking inactive users to active ones is more efficient and reliable. However, active users still make up the vast majority (refer to Table 1). If we directly connect inactive user to every active user, the refined social graph will be very dense. To tackle this problem, we creatively devise a U2C (user to cluster) addition mechanism. Instead of employing all active users, we firstly mine interest clusters in active users (or active interest clusters), and then learn how to establish connections towards these clusters to reduce space complexity.

Datasets. We employ four datasets, including two publicly available datasets [30] (i.e. Flickr, Yelp) and two real industrial datasets (i.e. AliData [30] (i.e. Flickr, Yelp) and two real industrial datasets (i.e. AliData I 𝐼 I italic_I , AliData I 𝐼 I italic_I I I 𝐼 𝐼 𝐼I Iitalic_I italic_I, AliData I ⁢ I 𝐼 𝐼 II italic_I italic_I ). AliData I ⁢ I 𝐼 𝐼 II italic_I italic_I I ⁢ I I I⁢ ⁢I I 𝐼 𝐼 𝐼 𝐼 𝐼 𝐼𝐼 𝐼II IIitalic_I italic_I italic_I italic_I). AliData I 𝐼 I italic_I represents a smaller-scale market with specific commodity categories and customer groups, where users have more sparse and concentrated behaviors. Contrarily, AliData I 𝐼 I italic_I I I 𝐼 𝐼 𝐼I Iitalic_I italic_I represents a smaller-scale market with specific commodity categories and customer groups, where users have more sparse and concentrated behaviors. Contrarily, AliData I ⁢ I 𝐼 𝐼 II italic_I italic_I covers a broader range of commodities and serves diverse customers with different shopping needs, where interactions are denser. To provide transparency regarding our selection of inactive users, we present the cutoff criteria for inactive user behavior of each dataset in Table  I ⁢ I 𝐼 𝐼 II italic_I italic_I I ⁢ I I I⁢ ⁢I I 𝐼 𝐼 𝐼 𝐼 𝐼 𝐼𝐼 𝐼II IIitalic_I italic_I italic_I italic_I covers a broader range of commodities and serves diverse customers with different shopping needs, where interactions are denser. To provide transparency regarding our selection of inactive users, we present the cutoff criteria for inactive user behavior of each dataset in Table 1.

Considering there is not definition of ‘inactive’ in selected public datasets (i.e., Flickr and Yelp), we also label the last 30% users as ‘inactive’ in Table 1. To address any concerns regarding ratio selection, we provide a comparison between DiffNet++ (the best baseline) and LSIR on Yelp, considering different ratios of inactive users. As shown in Fig. 4, LSIR outperforms DiffNet++ consistently and exhibits greater stability across various ratios of inactive users. Therefore, the selection of ratio will influence less on the performance of LSIR.

references: In this subsection, we aim to validate the effectiveness of LSIR on recommendation. Specifically, we report the performances on Top-10/20 recommendation for inactive users in Table 2, and NDCG@10 results for active and overall users in Table 3, where we focus on social recommenders. The conclusions are as follows:

LSIR is competitive constantly in both active and overall user cases. As shown in Fig. 3, LSIR consistently achieves the best or second-best performance across all users in both academic and industrial datasets. This indicates that the proposed refinement process will not sacrifice the performance on active and overall users. LSIR successfully strikes a balance between enhancing recommendation quality for inactive users while maintaining or even improving performance for active and overall users.

references: To evaluate the effectiveness of designed GSL component in LSIR, we replace this part with two other GSL methods IDGL [2] and GAUG  [2] and GAUG [37], denoted as LSIR+IDGL and LSIR+GAUG. In addition, we have a baseline variant, LSIR+UU, where the original social graph remains unchanged. We compare these variants with our model, and report [37], denoted as LSIR+IDGL and LSIR+GAUG. In addition, we have a baseline variant, LSIR+UU, where the original social graph remains unchanged. We compare these variants with our model, and report NDCG@10 and NDCG@20 on inactive users on Yelp and AliData I 𝐼 I italic_I in Table  I 𝐼 I italic_I I I 𝐼 𝐼 𝐼I Iitalic_I italic_I in Table 4. From the table, we observe that LSIR+GAUG fails to run on AliData I 𝐼 I italic_I due to its high space complexity. LSIR+IDGL performs even worse than LSIR+UU because it neglects some important users in its random anchors. Additionally, we explore the effectiveness of U2C addition and U2U deletion individually. The results, as shown in the Table  I 𝐼 I italic_I I I 𝐼 𝐼 𝐼I Iitalic_I italic_I due to its high space complexity. LSIR+IDGL performs even worse than LSIR+UU because it neglects some important users in its random anchors. Additionally, we explore the effectiveness of U2C addition and U2U deletion individually. The results, as shown in the Table 4, indicate that the absence of the U2C addition component leads to a larger drop in performance compared to the absence of the U2U deletion component. This indicates that for inactive users, high-quality supplement is more valuable than deleting limited neighbors.

To evaluate the effectiveness of designed GSL component in LSIR, we replace this part with two other GSL methods IDGL [2] and GAUG  [2] and GAUG [37], denoted as LSIR+IDGL and LSIR+GAUG. In addition, we have a baseline variant, LSIR+UU, where the original social graph remains unchanged. We compare these variants with our model, and report [37], denoted as LSIR+IDGL and LSIR+GAUG. In addition, we have a baseline variant, LSIR+UU, where the original social graph remains unchanged. LSIR+IDGL performs even worse than LSIR+UU because it neglects some important users in its random anchors. Additionally, we explore the effectiveness of U2C addition and U2U deletion individually. The results, as shown in the Table 4, indicate that the absence of the U2C addition component leads to a larger drop in performance compared to the absence of the U2U deletion component.
